print_settings.Notes:: If you really trust your printer you can try the 35° version, its more egg-shaped but needs good material and print settings to work.

description.text:
My take of an Easter egg. It's two pieces that screw together to hide candy or other things, maybe even other eggs.

I designed it to be easy to print, the bottom overhang is only 45°(35° if you choose, "egg_35deg_overhang.STL"). I use big bottle threads to minimize warping. The walls are 2mm-4mm thick (you should be able to scale the model but the clearance might become a problem).

Printer:

Perfect 3D

Supports:

No

Notes:

Print "egg" (bottom part) and "egg2" (top part).

If you really trust your printer you can try the 35° version, its more egg-shaped but needs good material and print settings to work.

print_settings.Notes:: I recommend printing with 100% infill and only a single shell layer. This helps with the detail on the front.

description.text:
This is a keychain with the 2017 March For Science logo embossed on the front, and a variety of cutouts or phrases debossed on the back. Print out a bunch and hand them out during the event!

If you want any different phrases on the back, write a comment and I'll upload some additions. Or grab the Fusion archive and make your own changes.

title: 3D printing tool holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a holder for the tools I use for 3D printing. So far it has 5 holders for small tools like scissors, tweezers, knife, feeler gauges or pencils. The holder also features slots for a caliper a paint scraper and a 2mm allen wrench for my M200. There is also a small container in the back and a bigger, removable one for things, like the excess filament that is extruded in the beginning of a print.

Feel free to edit the slots and holders, to fit your tools.

Measurements:

tool holder base: 100mm x 100mm

small holders: 15 mm diameter

author: Riffcaster

description.text:
I often had problems with replacing the filament (filament leftover in the extruder) and I was tired of always disassembling the fan so I decided to make the fan movable.

My modification is a kind of hinge. One half is attached to the extruder with two 3x25mm screws.
The other half is screwed together with two 3x30mm screws and two 3mm nuts.

ATTENTION: It's important to sink in the holes of the aluminium block to make the screws flush with the block.

Additionally I use the Anet A8 Extruder Fan Spacer by AZDawg (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1798669) which I customized so the fan sits flush on the aluminium block.

Both parts are screwd together with one 3x40mm screws and two 3mm nuts.

The aluminiun block does not bear directly on the extruder anymore so some of you might say that it isn't of use anymore.
Thats right you lost the cooling effect but I do not recognize any change in the results with PLA.
For ABS this MOD is maybe not good because highter temp on the extruder.
However the positive effect is noticeable as you have fast and easy access to the filmanet loader.

So everyone who is tired of disassembling the fan each time he has problems with the loader is welcome to use my modification to improve his own printer.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

comments.author: iksav

comments.text:
VERY bad idea. In this configuration cold end has even less cooling than it would have if fan and heatsink were simply removed, as plastic partially insulates lower block.
But, not entirely useless: if this still works with PLA (do not try ABS!) maybe smaller, passive heatsink, still exposing extruder tube, would work, too. Time to find a thermometer and do some tests.
comments.author: bashfullsson

comments.text: Hadco, you inspired me to  try  and learn more about making things - so I remixed your gate and hinge for the reasons others give about it being difficult.  In mine I  added support to the  hinge because my prints  kept snapping off.    On the subject of the heat sink. Lets remember that Anet cloned ( an excuse word to say they copied it) Joe Prusa basic design and copped out on quality and logic.  have any detractors actually opened the  "gate" - while the A8 is printing and  right away touch the  heat sink to see how hot it gets??   I have and  its not that hot that it makes any difference if you  throw it  in the trash. I know many who don't use the  heatsink OR the fan at all..... none have any problems.  I think we all use it  just because its there!
comments.author: ABW-3D

comments.text: I think that it would be better without the heat sink, so the fan can blow on the extruder body, since there's no thermal contact between the heat sink and the carriage,
comments.author: evvo

comments.text:
I hope you know this mod is a COMPLETE fail.
The use of the alloy radiator is to transfer heat from the Extruder into the air, the fan is there so more air passes the radiator. Therefore it obviously has to touch the black metal block where the nozzzle is screwed in because this is where the heat is coming from.
Here it only touches plastic which is a thermal insulator.
This has as much use as just useful as taping radiator and fan to any random position on the printer or- just not installing it at all.
Please take this design down, for serious. It looks nice but this is all it does.
comments.author: Tryptonite

comments.text: I have to second this. Plus the fact that your fan seems to be mounted inverted, it sucks the radiator and doesn't blow on it. That might be the reason why you (hadoko) didn't notice any change. Honestly i thing this configuration would be the same as don't using the cooling at all.. did you try printing with the lid open?
comments.author: Tryptonite

comments.text: My fan is blowing in the right direction I use this mod 2 month befor I make my second mod. All work fine with it. If anyone dont line my mod or it dosnt work he dont need to use it. I only work with pla so maybe thats the reason I have no Probs with hihg temps. So the only positiv change is the easy way to change the filament but this is what I want!
comments.author: McUsher

comments.text: I sounded a bit harsh, sorry. The fan was just a guess, as mine blows towards the sticker side and yours looks identical to mine. But your design helped me figuring out, that MY fan was mounted backwards. Just did a stringing test, and indeed, my bad heat dissipation seems to be the reason to stringing for me. So i have to thank you :)
comments.author: hadoko

comments.text: I applaud the initiative but, I would advise against reducing the ability to shed heat from your cold end. Even with original design (heat sink adjacent to extruder) if you leave the hot end on for too long then you will get "heat creep" into your cold end which will create a gnarly jam requiring disassembly of the whole thing. Having to take everything apart, clear the jam/replace parts, reassemble, and relevel the bed is way more of a PITA than changing filament -- trust me. Top Tip: If you employ this, be sure NOT to keep your hot end at operating temp for very long without running filament through it to dissipate the heat.

comments.text:
Hello
It's realy a good idea, but there is a problem: the radiator must be in contact with the metalic mass of the extruder in order to dissipate the heat to allows the stepper motor does not heat.
This is not the case with this modification because the radiator in isolated from the extruder metalic mass by a plastic part.

It just basically blocks air from getting the motor and gears. That being said, I know a lot of people that don't even bother with a cooling fan for the heat block in the hot end.  So maybe it doesn't matter.

remixed_from.title: Z Endstop Fine Adjustment Prusa i3 - Anet A8

title: Anet A8 - Z Endstop Fine Adjustment
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Updates 30/07/2017
Uploaded a version with a bigger hole around Z motor shaft, so now it is completely usable for those people willing to use plum couplers. Still has the gap on the inner side, so it's pretty easy to reach the couplers' setscrews with an allen wrench.
Regarding the X motor piece, now it is 2mm wider, and has a slightly shorter stroke, since there's no need of 20+mm stroke for such a precise thing. Additionaly, I moved the holes upwards, because with 3mm glass sheet mine was almost at the end of its stroke. Also moved the vertical hole 3mm closer to X motor front plate, so now it lines up almost perfect with the endstop wheel. Still, I recommmend using a nylock nut at the bottom end of the bolt in order to increase contact area without printing too small parts.
I will upload pictures as soon as I have assembled the new version of both pieces.

This is a remix of Meermeneer Z Endstop Fine Adjustment for Anet A8. I made it more rigid, so now the motor piece should be bolted to all four holes of the stepper motor. Besides, I made the top part a bit bigger, so it has some more travel, just enough to have a 3mm borosilicate glass plate on the heated bed.

I recommend using a M3x20mm allen bolt for the fine adjustment. You'll need M3x18 for the stepper.

You might have to drill a little bit for the fine adjustment bolt hole. In that case, grab a pair of pliers, and just twist a 2.5mm diameter drill bit to remove some more microns. Then just use some mineral oil and fasten the bolt with the allen wrench.

It could be changed a little bit to fit 1/8" bolts in case you live in the US, just let me know via comment.

There are some minor changes between the version installed in my printer and the one available here, mostly reinforced corners and some chamfers,

Printer:

Anet A8

These are conversion charts I use as part of my scale model workflow. When I create my furniture pieces, I often design directly in scale. To do so, I need to translate real world measurements into scale and into mm. I keep these charts handy to make things easier. I also put together a scale ruler for each, that shows inches, mm and scale feet for the given scale all on one page. Check out my post on the subject on MakerBot's blog: http://www.makerbot.com/blog/2012/05/04/makerbot-miniatures-developing-a-workflow/

Conversion Charts available:
1:12
1:16
1:18
1:24
1:48
1:96 The charts follow this basic equation:
((Feet12) +Inches) (scale factor) * (metric conversion factor) = dimension in scale, in mm Make sure to print these files at 100% - do not "scale to fit page". Double check the printed rulers before using. For a limited time, I'll take requests to add more scales to the list if folks are interested. Enjoy!

description.text:
IMPORTANT!!! - If you do end up printing this, be sure to print the baffle (the part the speaker mounts to) with a relatively high infill percent, if not entirely solid. Or you could have at least 6-7 exterior walls. When you go to mount the driver with screws, you will want something for the screws to dig into. I had to use T nuts to mount my drivers, and using T nuts in the thin plastic can be kind of sketchy. Just a heads up :)

This is a spherical ported speaker enclosure that I designed for the Dayton PS95-8 3.5" full range driver. (Link here: http://www.parts-express.com/dayton-audio-ps95-8-3-1-2-point-source-full-range-driver-8-ohm--295-349)

I first started this as an experiment but I eventually developed this design for them. The enclosures are .11 cu ft tuned to 74hz. I included the STL for the sphere portion and port portion, however if your printer is large enough I also included the full model. The stand is in there as well. If anyone does decide to make this, I'd be happy to hear from you. Knowing someone made something from my design would be very rewarding for me.

Note: the stand and full model aren't oriented correctly. The stand should just be printed flat, and the full model should probably be printed baffle down (I haven't printed it so I can't say, but you can probably be the judge of this).

Here is an album showing progress pictures, assembly and the finished product.

http://imgur.com/a/zdeJB

Thanks for looking!

Maker Select V2

comments.text: Hi! Thanks for the great design. I was curious how much filament you used for the print? If I make the sphere a high infill it looks like each sphere will use about 2/3rds a roll of filament on their own? Does that seem right?
comments.author: bmeissen

comments.text: Yes, that sounds right. I used about 700g of filament for the entire thing, and fairly low infill (5% I believe). If you go higher than 5% I could see the infill adding up pretty quick as you print it. I honestly don't believe that a higher infill will yield a stronger enclosure. As long as you have enough walls then that's going to make up most of your strength. I'd love to experiment sometime with infill percentages and the effect it has on resonances within the enclosure.

title: BXA (200) series quick change lathe tool holder rack.

description.text:
I have a small Grizzly lathe that has a sheetmetal back splash guard and I wanted to create some tool holders that keep my lathe tools on the sheetmetal. I retrofitted the factory cross slide tool holder with a Shars BXA series quick change holder that works very well.  
I made these so I can slide them over the sheet metal and hang the preset tools on the back for quick access. Some of the holders like the boring bars were just too heavy to use magnets, so this was the best way to do it.  
I printed these with 20% infill and made them to support a good amount of weight. I filleted the top to make it easier to swap tools on the holder. The groove in the back just slides over the sheetmetal and provides good solid support for taking them on and off.

Print at y our own risk. Still working on files.
Decided to redo the C-Bot/D-Bot files as I wanted to sturdy the frame with aluminum corner pieces. This allows room for the aluminum pieces to hold the frame together while the motor and idler ends are attached to the frame, hopefully keeping the printed pieces from strain. It gets to 120 degrees where I'm at and I planned on moving this around from time to time, so I wanted to build it as sturdy as possible. At the moment, all pieces are cut from Misumi T-Slot with the standard D-Bot build dimensions and a 2020 piece instead of a 2040 for the x gantry.This is why there is no middle indent for the T-slot, so it would work with either.

The starter is a lot in use for RC cars so version one broke after a while and the shaft just spinned around so in version two I added two screws to tighten the shaft.

Needs 2pcs M3 nuts and 2pcs M3x12 hex screws.

If your shaft is bigger than the design allows just drill it out a little bit and tighten the screws and it should still clamp.

Needed a motor driven air gate for a passive house heating system. Need to reality in 24 hours. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TT8sEII99wo Uses piano wire pushed into captive slots on gate flange to create slip clutch on drive shaft. I so wish thingiverse didnt try to "frame" your pictures, it just messes things up :-( It even seems to be rotating some of them, double :-( :-( Print a full set on one plate, or two at a time as per picture, as always raft, support and default 0.2 mm slicing.

comments.text: what size duct? and damper motor info also needed.most residential HVAC round pipe runs are 6" but some are different anywhere from 2" on Jetpack systems to 8" flex/fiberglass in 1" increments e.g. 5,6,7,8

title: Coin Tray for Nissan Leaf S 2015

description.text:
This is a coin tray for the Nissan Leaf S 2015. I would assume that it fits all Nissan leaf from 2011-2017, but maybe they have various versions of the center console, I really don't know.
Since there is nowhere to put any coins except loosely at the bottom of the center console, I remixed my own tray I did for the Mazda 6 to fit my newly acquired Leaf (amazing car if you don't think of its look!). Took me 5 tries before I got all the angles just right...

**April 23 2017: On request, I added a tray without the dividers in, if you want to put something bigger than coins. I also made one with just 1 divider, for a mix of big and small stuff :)

author: Barrocas

description.text:
The original canopy is very hard to print, with thin vertical walls that bend while printing, and huge bridging across the top.
My beautiful wife Juliette pointed out that it would be  much easier to print upside down, so I flipped it over and added thin walls across the openings to hold it steady as it's printing. So I modified the original SketchUp file slightly, and the result works.

Print it.
Cut out the thin covering over the openings.
Use it with the PL2Q Hugin just like the original.
For the rest of the parts, print the PL2Q Hugin. It rocks.

comments.text: This is excellent! I've had sooo much trouble printing the original, however, I printed this the first time and it's amazing! Fits and looks awesome!

title: Anet A8 Dual Extruder Cable Management

description.text:
NVBigBlue created and published a design for an Anet A8 Dual Extrusion upgrade (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1733096).
I am converting my Sintron Prusa I3 using this upgrade, and it works very well, but I chose not to go with the servo or inductive bed levelling options. Cable management is a bit tight on the X-carriage, so I designed and printed this Cable Management bracket which fits over the Carriage/Extruder mounting screws. All the extruder cables (extruders, thermistors, fans) are zip-tied to the bracket.

Use 2.5mm or 3.6mm cable ties.
Route cables very carefully to relieve strain on Thermistor wires, and Heater Cartridge wires.

title: Lasercut Insert for 4in Deep Stackable Trays
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Removable insert for my extreme deep-dish storage solution (13" x 13" x 4" deep tray) for game tiles or other collections http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2219928, which seats neatly with my previously published Ikea Expedit or Kallax storage shelf/bookcase trays.

Designed for easy insert and removal and this insert can hold modest amounts of weight. The provided template uses up blank space that you might have with other cutting patterns or left over scrapes that are at least 5 inches wide or deep. The insert will fit in the corners and maybe the sides of the dividers for the extreme deep dish tray but not the middle.

I also use one of these as PLA garbage tray in my 3D printer utility shelf http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2098301 to collect all those bits of raft, supports and failed prints.

Formatted for cutting on two 3mm MDF cut from (Arch C) 24" x 18" sized sheets, which each fit across the bed of an Epilog Helix. I have provided the PDF and a SVG files that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. And if you download this, please LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

title: Wanhao i3 Plus Bearing Spool Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Bearing Spool Holder for the Wanhao i3 Plus. Greatly reduces filament feed drag.

Simply screw into stock spooler mount. Requires 2 x 608 (8x22x7mm) style bearings commonly used in skateboards, inline skates, etc.

Please note for optimal performance, its best to sand down any ridges on the spool shaft.

Updated original design to allow for plenty of clearance between spool and top frame. Removed 70mm spool holder.

Connecting bearing mating part dimensions have been sized with a .5mm difference - ID (7.95mm) and OD (22.05mm) than a standard 608 bearing 8mm ID x 22mm OD x 7mm width. My final prints came out with a snug press fit for the bearings.

comments.text: Works really nice! Thank you for the design. Works well even without the bearings (Ordered my bearings on aliexpress but they haven't arrived yet.) Also works with the original spool holders nut. You might want to mention that!
comments.author: MrShhh

comments.text: I made one of these. It works great. Actually in some cases a little too great. It's reduced the resistance against the filament feed so much that occasionally with some slightly stiffer filaments it overspins the roll and causes the filament to jump off sideways just from the extruder feed alone. This seems most prone to happen on a new roll of filament where there isn't much of a spool wall to keep it corralled. Just something to watch for. Reducing the friction on the spool does seemingly reduce a lot of missed extrusions.

comments.text: is there a benefit printing in two halves?
comments.author: westcpw

comments.text: There really can be. I get better detail when I print things horizontally, especially on things like faces and spears and such. You get a slight seam, though it's far less pronounced if you print without a raft (especially if you're printing ABS onto kapton or PLA onto a heated glass bed). For these kinds of models at this scale, I feel that it beats cleaning up support (which only does so much to protect the details anyway).

author: JML31347

description.text:
One of the minor issues with the A8 is that the 5 control push buttons wobble a little in the guide holes, sometimes resulting in a non functioning button press. A previous printable fix was made that you applied behind the acrylic face plate. Then in late 2016 / early 2017 Anet made the guide holes smaller, rendering the printed fix useless, whilst the smaller holes didn't actually fix the problem.
My solution effectively makes the buttons slightly thicker and eliminates the problem. The button caps rely on a friction fit. If like mine, one button is smaller by a fraction of a millimetre, I secured the button with a blob of Blu-tack (Tack-It, Plasti-tac, sticky-tac, presstik - the sticky blobby stuff you put posters up with as a kid).
Don't glue the button caps on, or you will never get the control circuit board off the acrylic face plate again.

The walls of the button are VERY thin and require a little finesse with the slicer. I used Cura 2.3.1 (settings below)

The nice thing about this solution is it's another mod you can use to customise the look your printer.

I have included the original 123D files if you need / want to experiment.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Because of the thin walls on the button, you need to make quite a few setting changes in your slicer and print it slowly.

Cura 2.3.1 settings for 1.75mm PLA

Layer height : 0.1mm
Wall thickness : 0.4mm
Top / bottom pattern : Concentric (not important, I just think it looks good on a round button)
Z-seam: shortest or back
Infil line distance: 0.4mm
Print temp : 200 (but try with your standard for PLA)
Bed temp: 50 (but try with your standard for PLA)
Print speed: < 50mm/s

I printed mine with a z-seam rather than the random. My thinking was any problem with the seam would be easier to remove if it were in a single place. As it turned out, the buttons are not all exactly the same and the tiny seam on a couple of them helped secure the buttons tightly.
On the outer edge of the thin shaft wall, any seam must be removed, so it doesn't bind on the acrylic. I used a sharp xacto blade. You could sand it lightly. The side wall is very delicate. It's strong enough for a button, but aggressive sanding will break it.

123D design. Three simple cylinders. It wasn't rocket science.
Quite a few test prints to get the friction fit spot on.

author: kkirkov

description.text:
This is a tension arm for the QU-BD MBE Extruder. It works with a 608 bearing that is commonly used for skates, roller blades and other similar things. The bearing can be inexpensive, since this is a low speed operation you don't need high ABEC ratings. This will work with the standard raptor gear in i'ts normal position using the groove. The clearance is tight but it works. The head of the feed tube screw hits the bearing with no filament but once the filament it is in it clears fine and runs smoothly. I started getting my best prints once I put this in place. This arm is stronger than some of the others that I have seen, printed and tried to use. Especially if you are going to print this with PLA. I found other designs to warp easily from the heat of the extruder and bed rising up. This design is inspired by the spring tensioner from Barton Dring.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:38281

description.header: Note: use MK7 gear if you have one
description.text:
I printed the arm shown using PLA at 400 microns (.4mm). Use a 608 bearing and the screw is there to provide lateral strength against the whole arm, it's not there to keep the bearing in place. The bearing is not going anywhere between the arm and the heatsink. Of course if you don't have the heat sink you can use a button head bolt and washer. Depending on your printer and settings the pivot hole might be tight, and you may need to drill it out a bit so that it pivots smoothly. This works with the spring block from Barton Dring.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:38281 For arms mounted on the opposite side, use a scale of -1 in your printer settings across the proper axis to flip it. I do this using Repetier Host, make sure you unlock the scales so they don't all flip. I was using a raptor gear but the MK7 works much better with this arm. My original arm was printed at 400 microns and works great, no warping or deforming after many hours of printing. If you are using PLA and want some peace of mind, increase to 200 microns and 80% infill. The top fill pattern is concentric.

title: Filament Filter and Wire Holder for Creality CR-10

description.text:
These two parts are intended to solve three problems with the Creality CR-10 3D printer.

  1. It provides an enclosure in which one can place a sponge to filter dust off the filament and allow for the application of lubrication oil. The top cap pushes the sponge down so its snug against the filament.
  2. It holds the filament far enough from the z-axis screw so that machine oil won't get on the filament and so it won't get snagged.
  3. On its side there is a small opening through which one can thread a zip tie so that one can attach the black wiring bundle leading to the extruder to the platform on Bracket1.stl. Often times this wiring bundle gets in the way of prints. Because a zip tie is used the wiring bundle won't be 100% firmly fixed in place which is good since it will allow a little bit of flex to be in place.

This piece is intended to be attached to the wheel immediately adjacent to the extruder motor using the same nut that is used to attach this same wheel. This is a two piece assembly. I used supports to hold up Bracket1.stl. I don't know if this piece can be printed without supports

description.text:
Update: Calibration ruler test file added (in mm). Plots a ruler of 10mm on X and Y axis, using Z axis with a pen. Simulates an axis, drives an RC Servo instead. Want to use a servo in GRBL for the Z axis, but don't want to change your firmware too much? This quick hack is designed as a drop- in replacement for a stepper driver such as the easydriver or Pololu driver.
It reads the DIR and STEP signals and converts an internal step counter into PWM for an RC servo. Great for use in existing hardware. No fundamental changes in firmware are needed. You can of course build three and have your whole machine run on RC servos. :-) You will need an ATtiny 25/45/85 running at 8 MHz. Detailed schematics will follow when I find the time. For further information see code. Made for my DVD drive plotter, now running GRBL and accepting true gcode :-)
http://youtu.be/KZ46Kgq2LHk I HEREBY CANNOT BE HELD RESPONSIBLE FOR ANY DAMAGE THIS PROGRAM/UNIT MAY CAUSE. BY DOWNLOADING YOU AGREE TO THIS TERM.

title: P3 Steel Lead Screw Top (608zz bearing)

description.text:
Hi,

I have remixed the two parts in the original to be one part that fits the Orballo version of the P3Steel frame.

The lead screw hole will need to be worked with an 8/9mm drill bit as I have not adjusted the original measurements.

The Lead screw holes will need to be worked with a 10mm drill bit as I found that the screw was fouling on the original hole.

You will also need to file where the frame slides in as I have given zero tolerance, not doing so will crack the part!

The original design worked great, however I felt that I needed a more fixed alignment

comments.text: I too am building an Orbalio frame version P3 Steel .. but with smaller 1/4" leadscrew and larger 10mm smooth rods. (stepped 8mm ends).  My preference is to use larger smooth rods for stability and guidance, and as small and flexible a lead screw as possible with NO top bearing constraint. Any wobble or run out in a large lead screw, especially if constrained at top end with a bearing,  will overwhelm an 8mm guide rod, causing your layers to not line up.

This is a lasercut plate to hold a breadboard and an arduino mega or uno, plus some dials and switches. It allows for easy prototyping and demonstrations on the go. 
My idea with this is to lower the boundary to testing and prototyping my ideas as quickly as possible. If I have to make a circuit board, or start soldering to test something, I'll be much less likely to do it than if I can just plug everything in in a few seconds.

Parts list:
Arduino mega, Uno or similar. You can get these pretty much anywhere, and I'd reccomend the mega since it's got IO pins to spare. Qty 4 - 20mm M3 spacers. Altronics H1250, $5.10 for a pack of 8. http://www.altronics.com.au/index.asp?area=item&id=H1250
Qty Many - Some Misc M3 screws to fasten these in place.
Qty 3 - 16mm linear 10K pot, with spline. R2225 from Altronics http://www.altronics.com.au/index.asp?area=item&id=R2225
Qty 3 - Stylish plastic knobs. For that touch of class H6109 from Altronics http://www.altronics.com.au/index.asp?area=item&id=H6109
Qty 3 - toggle switch S1315 from Altronics http://www.altronics.com.au/index.asp?area=item&id=S1315 Some long standard breadboard, is also needed. I found some that was 165mm long and 55mm tall. They usually come with adhesive backing, but if it doesn't, just use a few lines of double sided tape to secure it. An assortment of nice hookup wires are handy. Here's some short ones in Male-Male:
http://littlebirdelectronics.com/products/premium-jumper-wire-50-piece-rainbow-assortment-m-m-6 The plastic tub is a Fisher 1H-032 box, which has a nice snap fastener on the lid and is very robust. about $7 at 'Howard's Storage World', but a few places have them.
Dimensions are rectangular and about 66H,136D & 195W outside, and 60H, 128D and 186W inside (mm). Cutting:
Use the DXF file, and make sure to set up your power levels so that everything except the outline and the holes are engraving or scoring, not cutting. My laser software doesn't allow me to import different colours respectfully, so this isn't done yet. Assembly:
Use the adhesive tape and secure the breadboard onto the scored cutout showing it's position. Use the spacers and some M3 nuts and bolts and secure the arduino to the table. Put the plate together with all the switches and knobs, and wire them up. I used 5V and 0V on ends of the pots, and had all the switches connect an input pin to ground when on, and float when off. If you use analog inputs to the left of the board, and get 5V and 0V from the digital connector, you can still mount a standard shield on the arduino, which is handy. Cut the holes to allow the USB & DC jack to pass through your box.

title: G1/8 "Y-piece" 1.75mm dual extrusion upgrade ( prometheus system ) ( 1/8PT ) CaptKirk Revision

description.text:
This is a quick, untested revision of SilasPfeifer's dual color extruder piece. I like the Prometheus concept for dual color as a single hot end is easier to tune and use. The difference on this one is that on the end where the two filament colors come in, I enlarged the feed tubes to allow the bowden teflon tubing to extend through the connectors and all the way down to the intersection of the "Y". I did this because I think the filament will be hot when a color is retracted and I wanted it to sit in teflon instead of against the printed plastic where I think it could stick.

I plan to test this once I finish up building my second printer (a CoreXY based design of my own).

What do you think??

comments.text: I've printed many shapes like this and with my Printrbot, I do not have to use support. I have to still try this but my print station is torn up right now due to repair work being done to my house due to tree fall damage during all the storms here in California this winter.

description.text:
This is a self-starting siphon. Submerge it in your friend's drink, and in about a second it will automatically start spilling out the other end. Unlike a normal siphon, you don't need to suck on the end or prime it with water first.

This thing is magic. When showing it to people I've found the more physics they've studied the more surprised they are! Flinn Scientific suggests capillary action is required for the fluid level to rise higher than the container level in the "up hill" part. The capillary action is helpful, but I think momentum alone is enough for the phenomenon. What do you think?

See it in action: https://youtu.be/VaST4ummiUg
More thorough explanation of how it works: https://youtu.be/4SEv_GxAo70

Based on the design suggested by FlinnScientific here (took some trial and error):
https://www.flinnsci.com/globalassets/flinn-scientific/all-free-pdfs/dc10499.pdf

OnShape CAD model:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/b07bf072535b6507e7963b8e/w/7f50381e76bfccd023bc7222/e/86e868e1153b984ab71a134f

Tips:
Submerge the siphon quickly, ensuring the entire elbow dips below the surface level. Hold it there for a second or two until water flows out the other end. If it doesn't work, blow through one end of the siphon to clear out any trapped water and try again.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Doesnt matter

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print with 100% infill, no support. Use transparent plastic if you have it so that you can see the fluid travel inside of the siphon.

I may add designed-in rafts in a future version if many people have issues with the ends lifting during printing.
https://www.flinnsci.com/globalassets/flinn-scientific/all-free-pdfs/dc10499.pdf
https://www.flinnsci.com/globalassets/flinn-scientific/all-free-pdfs/dc10499.pdf

title: H&K; USP Compact With Removable Suppressor

description.text:
This is a remix of hackervincent's H&K model, modified to have a removable suppressor. The final version is a lot of fun to play with, but could definitely use a rebuild. It looks like a low poly game model, and some parts are a bit blocky.

I'm new to 3D printing, so I went looking for cool models and found this beauty. The only issue was it looks like it was pulled straight from a game, and was not directly printable in the original version.

Printer:

Maker Select V2.1

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20

Assembly

The best way to put this together is gluing the barrel insert into one side of the gun, then gluing the other side onto both the insert and the first gun half. This allows the insert to help with the aligning of the sides, and you don't have to worry about it not being able to go in because the sides aren't glued properly.

As a note, it's best to do a quick dry fit before gluing. I tried to make the tolerances big enough so the insert would be tight but clear the receiving hole. If the halves won't go together flush with the insert in place, some sanding might be needed before final assembly.

Goal

My goal was primarily to make this awesome gun printable. I also wanted to print the suppressor separately, as vertical cylinders tend to come out looking better and don't need supports.

I also wanted to print the gun in 2 big pieces, splitting it down the middle. I intended for it to be more like a toy, but this was definitely the quickest way to get all of the outside parts printed smoothly without supports, and a little finish will make the small seam disappear.

Clean Up

I used the free Microsoft tool (https://tools3d.azurewebsites.net/) and Mesh Mixer for the bulk of the cleaning. It looks like a game model, and they always need a little help.

I ended up fully remaking the suppressor in Blender because the original was so faceted. This was could still be smoother, which I only realized after it printed.

Finally, I used Mesh Mixer to split the gun up and do a last pass for errors.

Suppressor Threads

I decided on a barrel insert with threads, and matching threads on the receiving end of the suppressor. This was done because I didn't want to print the threads in half with the rest of the gun, and possibly not have them line up right after gluing.

This was my first time ever modeling threads, much less ones that were designed to be functional. They came out alright, and hold just fine, but could definitely use some polish. I made them a bit aggressive so 1) I could put the suppressor on with just a few turns like a movie star, and 2) so I could get my pliers in there to remove the support material.

For example, the number of "steps" blender uses could be bumped up, and the transition at the end of the threads could definitely be better.

author: BigJ89

description.text:
This is a double helical geared fidget spinner. Friction fit between bearings. No additional hardware needed. The center bearing is held in place by surrounding gears.

You'll need to print:
4 x DoubleHelixGear
2 x Spinner
2 x Bearing Button

Used four 22mm bearings (608Z)

Print the gears, spinners, and buttons. You'll need to push the bearings into the gears, this might require pliers but be careful not to break the gears. Push the bearing buttons into each side of one of the bearings. Next, we need to push one of the bearings onto the spinner piece, this may require pliers also. Then line up the bearing that has the buttons in the middle of the spinner piece making sure that the gears fit interlocking with the gears on the bearing that is attached to the spinner. Then push the other two bearings onto the spinner piece ensuring that the gears line up with the middle bearing gears. Finally push the other spinner piece into the bearings to finish assembly.

Please let me know if there are any improvements that can be made!

title: Anet A8 (Prusa) Y Axis Tensioner Improved Design

description.text:
This is an improved Y axis tensioner for Anet A8 printers. The bearing on the original design is constrained by pressure from the axial bolt, and is unable to rotate freely, resulting in unnecessary wear on the belt. And of course, is not adjustable.

My design uses the original bearings, but spaced so doesn't rub against the sides, and can move freely. Both halves can be adjusted separately so you can get the belt running centred, and adjust the tension within a small range.

Used in conjunction with my Y Axis Belt Clamp (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2249112), is a complete solution for your Y axis power transfer system.

Please leave a comment if you like...

Edit: July 16th 2017: I've changed the design slightly to bring the pulley in line with the motor pulley.

description.text:
You have two parts that clamp to digital callipers and enable a precise measurement of how much filament (1.75mm) is drawn into the extruder when you are calibrating it.

One part clamps to the end of the calliper and has a PTFE tube inserted into it. The other end of the tube goes to the extruder.

It does not matter if the extruder does not have a fitting to take the tube as long as the end of the tube buts up against the hole in filament clamp for instance and the filament can be drawn freely though the tube.

The other part clamps to the moving jaw of the calliper and has a clamp for the filament coming from the filament roll.

To use it just slacken off the filament clamp screw, close the jaws on the calliper, tighten the filament clamp screw and zero the calliper. Then run 100mm of filament through the extruder as per a normal extruder calibration.

The calliper gives you a direct reading of how much filament was actually drawn into the extruder.

Note: In the early stages of calibration it may be best to only run 50mm of filament as the calipers (well, the ones I have) will have a max travel of about 105mm with the parts clamped to them.

description.text:
I needed to secure a patio door and used a 3/8" bolt into a T nut pushed into the patio door and hidden underneath the existing hardware door lock plate (see photo). The only problem with my fix was I needed to leave a wrench by the door in case of emergency. By 3D printing a knob and pushing the bolt through it I could easily open and close the door when needed which in winter is not at all. It is nice that the bolt pulls the door against the weatherstripping making a nice tight seal.

I've been transitioning to Fusion360 but I knew what was needed for this knob and wanted a quick fix instead of a learning experience. I also saved the time and $4 not going to Lowes. I'll get back to F360 soon.

NOTES:
-Version 2 has a slightly tapered head with the ribs cut back. Due to some misalignment of the door the first knob was rubbing on the frame, this one won't rub. This version has a slight misalignment and will require some sanding to get the bolt to fit, recommend printing Version 3 instead.
-Version 3 was rebuilt once it was noticed version 2 was slightly off center.

title: RS Gimbal for Mobuis HD camera for Nex Neo quad - UPDATED Feb 2014

description.text:
Brushless gimbal for Mobius HD camera. Feb 2014 UPDATED files after final fitting to Neo Quad. Files for both original brushless gimbal motors, and the slightly smaller 2206 motor. In both cases the roll motor has been flipped around to get the motor-wiring on the inside, non rotating, part of the frame. The frame mounts are both with and without added support for printing. The specific parts for the 2206 motors are marked with "HK2206" in the file names. The Vtx and camera mounts are the same for both versions. Updated Files for optional parts to fit a 25mm or 33mm fpv camera (left or right), and the Vtx directly to the gimbal base (to increase the mass for improved dampening). Designed around 2206/2208 gimbal motors. Fully adjustable for tuning CG. Designed for the Nex Neo quad, but can be adapted for many other uses (a fixed wing version is also in the works). It is a straight fit for the Neo and replaces the original camera bracket (the holes should be opened up to 4 or 4,5mm for easier inserting the rubber dampers). It has built in rubber dampers for jello free video. Total weight without camera is only about 100-115 grams (motors and plastic parts). This weight is without the vtx and fpv camera mount (these weigh about 10-15 grams). Here are the motors used:
HK2206: http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__43037__2206_140Kv_Brushless_Gimbal_Motor_Ideal_for_GoPro_style_Cameras_.html
2208: http://www.ebay.com/itm/Brushless-Gimbal-Motor-2208-KV80-for-Gopro-3-ge-/281221303619?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_0&hash=item417a188d43 These are the rubber dampers:http://www.ebay.com/itm/Flexible-Screw-Pin-Rivet-60pcs-X-Rubber-Mount-For-Anti-Vibration-Fans-PC-Case-/181218754794?ssPageName=ADME:L:OC:US:1120

l’objectif est de transformer sa plaque d’essai en châssis de voiture pour passer directement aux essais de roulages.
Cet équipement se fait à l’aide d’un kit rapide à installer et à enlever si l’on souhaite retrouver sa plaque d’essai (breadboard) d’origine.

Caractéristiques :
-Kit pouvant être ajouté à la plaque d’essai (breadbord) de manière provisoire ou définitive suivant le mode de fixation ( collier Rilsan, double face, colle à chaud, élastique ou fil métallique…)
-Les composants sont facile et rapide à monter ou à enlever du kit.
-Le kit n’est pas dédié un un programme particulié.
-Après essai la plupart des pièces du kit peuvent être fixées par vissage sur un support définitif (plaquette en plastique ou bois ...)

Le kit se compose de supports pour fixer les composants suivants :

  • plaque d’essai 830 points (Breadboard)

  • Arduino Uno ou Nano

  • Servo moteur SG90
  • Plastic motoréducteurs Dc 3V-6V , alimenté ici avec un L293D
  • Module HC-SR04
  • Capteur infrarouge type GP2D12 ou GP2Y0A02YK
  • Pile 9V
  • Interrupteur Ø 6 mm ou connecteurs femelles (voir vidéo)

Le kit se compose aussi de deux roues et d’un patin de glissement en remplacement d’ une roulette pivotante.

Prévoir : Des colliers Rilsan, de l’adhésif double face, connecteur 9V , boîtier Bloc Support Coupleur 4 Accus AA. L293D
Une vis à bois de 3 * 30 mm
Option : interrupteur (ici :Small switches 6 pins)
Les composants indiqués sont à titre d’exemple puisque le Kit n’est pas réduit à un seul projet.

! Remarque :Ce kit est en phase d’essai, il sera probablement actualisé et / ou complété d’un lien qui envoi à d’autres pièces.

Ce kit est actuellement en essai sur un projet de Yves Pelletier que je remercie pour le partage de ses projets et pour ses cours. Voir le site ci dessous :
http://electroniqueamateur.blogspot.fr/2013/09/robot-eviteur-dobstacles-version-10.html

SUPPORT : seulement sur "AvecSupport1.stl"

//New version : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2322381

Kit to transform a breadbord into an Arduino car

The objective is to transform its test plate into a car chassis to go straight to rolling tests.
This equipment is made with a quick kit to install and remove if you want to retrieve its original breadboard.

Characteristics :
-Kit can be added to the test plate (breadbord) temporarily or permanently according to the method of fixing (Rilsan collar, double face, hot glue, elastic or wire ...)
-The components are easy and quick to assemble or remove from the kit.
-The kit is not dedicated a particular program.
-After testing most parts of the kit can be fixed by screwing on a definitive support (plastic or wooden plate ...)

The kit consists of brackets for fixing the following components:

  • test plate 830 points (Breadboard)
  • Arduino Uno or Nano
  • Servo motor SG90
  • Plastic geared motors Dc 3V-6V, powered here with a L293D
  • Module HC-SR04
  • Infrared sensor type GP2D12 or GP2Y0A02YK
  • Battery 9V
  • Switch Ø 6 mm or sockets (see video)

The kit also consists of two wheels and a sliding pad instead of a swivel castor.

Provide:
Rilsan collars, double-sided adhesive, 9V connector, Block Holder Holder 4 Accus AA. L293D.
A wooden screw of 3 * 30 mm

Option: switch (here: Small 6 pins switches)
The components shown are examples, since the Kit is not reduced to a single project.

! Note: This kit is in the testing phase, it will probably be updated and / or supplemented with a link to other parts.

This kit is currently being tested on a project by Yves Pelletier that I thank for sharing its projects and for its courses. See the site below:
Http://electroniqueamateur.blogspot.fr/2013/09/robot-eviteur-dobstacles-version-10.html

description.text:
I designed this micro air blower to work with a small smoke generator for a model boat I am making. It uses a 6mm pager motor and I was very pleased with the amount of air it moves so I thought I would share it.

NOTE - Please separate the STL file in your slicing software as the parts are not aligned in the same Z axis - this was due to poor drawing convention on my part and Sketchup.

The impeller blade is just friction fit on my motor, but again you may need to fettle or use a dab of glue on yours.

A friend of mine asked me to print him a filter holder that he found online. I didn't like the way it looked and the dimensions, so I designed my own.

I printed this with PLA, just used a brim to make sure (3x1 layers, attached to the model). I used 5 bottom layers and 3 top layers. Tried to minimize empty coasting but you'd want to watch your retraction settings depending on your printer.

print_settings.Notes:: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/5ca86b800e5179beb8603669/w/347d82ae95c010c689c0dd67/e/7f54f0ada856c21e8dcbbb3a

description.text:
This is a fidget spinner that achieves the majority of its rotating mass from M12 nuts.
Not only do M12 nuts weigh more than other bearings, they are smaller and can be mounted creatively - this was my attempt at that.

Some simple maths:
Standard tri spinner: 12g bearing3 = 36g rotating mass
This spinner: 16g nut6 = 96g rotating mass

There is a little more to it than that, but that is beyond me!

Printer:

XYZ Da Vinci Mini W

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm Layer height

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Created in onshape - this is one of my first models!
I thought using bearing as weights for a fidget spinner was expensive and not heavy enough. Enter the M12 nut - these bad boys are cheap, heavy and really uniform in weight. This means even cheap bearings spin for minutes with a full payload. The spinner can be lightened by removing a set of nuts.
My bearings weighed ~12g each, these nuts are 16g each and there are 6 of them!

The nuts are quite tight to thread on intentionally - this will obviously depend on nozzle width and the precision of your printer. If they are a touch loose, you can easily lock two nuts together.

Please comment with thoughts and improvements to the design.

Link to file: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/5ca86b800e5179beb8603669/w/347d82ae95c010c689c0dd67/e/7f54f0ada856c21e8dcbbb3a

Step 1

Print the file

Step 2

Thread your 3-6 M12 nuts onto the arms, they will be very tight (you do not want these falling off at speed!).

Step 3

Press your bearing in - this should also be very tight, but friction fit. Freezing the bearing may help it fit, but be careful not to burn yourself.

Step 4

Spin, spin, spin!
I am a complete CAD novice, I followed the Onshape tutorials and had a crack at something a little different. There were some features I wanted to add, but I haven't figured this out yet!

This is my version of the MITS Altair 8800. I wanted to make as faithful a reproduction of this hallowed machine as I'm able, especially one which has a fully 3D faceplate. I did take a few liberties and didn't go through great pains to size it out properly, but I tried to make it as close to the real thing (or at least, Google Images of the real thing since I've never seen one in person) as possible.

This is the device that started a revolution. Read about it here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altair_8800. I first learned of this early personal computer from the book The Innovators: How a Group of Hackers, Geniuses, and Geeks Created the Digital Revolution. It's a great book which goes through the early days of computing all the way up to the modern internet age, detailing the work of such revolutionary geniuses as Lady Ada Lovelace, Charles Babbage, Alan Turing, Doug Engelbart, Bill Gates and Paul Allen, Steve Wozniak and Steve Jobs, Linus Torvalds, Richard Stallman, and many more less recognizable names.

There are a few (read, many) inaccuracies in this model, as it has no internals. I also haven't yet added the fan vents in the back since I wasn't able to find a good picture of the back of the device, although I know there is a fan back there. I might eventually make another version which uses an Arduino or something to make real blinky-blinky lights, but I doubt I'll get around to making anything which functions quite like the original--I'm not that smart. All I know is, making that rad 70s font from scratch was a lot of fun. There were some interesting typefaces back then.

Unfortunately my printer only has a 5x5x5" build area, so it doesn't seem to be able to produce this model. I tried sizing down the Altair's faceplate, but the sliced model looked like it wouldn't print properly, so I didn't even try. I'd be very interested to see someone with a quality printer make this in all it's glory!

Anyway, comments welcome!

title: Textured Sleeve for Pura Stainless Water Bottle

description.text:
I created this textured grip for the Pura Stainless Steel water bottle. (http://www.purastainless.com/) While the current grip made of silicone is just fine if you have a normal grip but if you are like my son who has low tone and does not have a normal grip, then you need a more textured grip to hold on to the bottle. I created this sleeve to solve that problem. I printed it out of Ninjaflex for both durability and to be able to slip on and off the bottle for cleaning.

Safety Note 1: The silicone used in Pura is food grade. Ninjaflex is not food grade. So if you have a user who will chew on the sleeve, do not use ninjaflex. Further do not used Ninjaflex for say the straw.

Safety Note 2: FDM printing is NOT food safe. It leave tiny holes where bacteria can grow. It is safe for this application as long as the user does not chew on the sleeve.

author: NilsRoe

description.text: Aliens from the classic game "Space Invaders"

Here is an insole design I made for indoor sport use. I have used them successfully while playing badminton.

The first print that I have made appeared surprisingly long lasting. They have already clearly exceeded the lifetime of the purchased insoles I used to use before.

Insole size is 42 (EU), the shoe I use is 9 1/2 (US)

I printed the thin blue bottom layer from ABS. Then used soft filament (TPU?) for the middle red layer. Finally the black sides I made from NinjaFlex (TPU) which was much softer than the middle layer.

I think it would be fine too only to print the top layer without the bottom ABS layers. I will go for this approach once my first pair eventually worn out.

My model assumes first print the ABS STL and then proceed printing the soft layer which in the model floats in air. If only planning to print the top layer one needs to offset the model to directly print on the bed.

description.text:
Having printed one of the original cogs, I found the base file to be too large and too thick for what I wanted, but I liked the step down on the cog, so this is a remixed file of 10 gears of different sizes, (numbers 15 to 24 of the original) with the z axis reduced by half.
Takes a little over an hour at 0.2 layer height.
Gives a good handful of light weight gears for steampunking up your costume.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30%

Punk it up

Print in black plastic for lightweight pieces and use 'old gold' spraypaint to steampunk them up. Sew or glue to your costume and be fabulous.

This is a remix - I printed the original and found it to be too thick, and I wanted to print more than one at once. I imported 10 gears of different sizes into Cura, and reduced the X and Y axes by 50%. I reduced the z axis to 25% to reduce the thickness while keeping the step down on the gear.
Exported the file to .stl
Remake thanks turned out good

description.text: This is something simple I designed that I wanted on my machine to un-inhibit the viewing of things being printed. It uses standard 5mm LEDs.

Print with 1 extra shell to allow for drilling of your holes if necessary. Mount to hole behind extruder with M5 bolt and nut (or equivalent).
Wire your LEDs in series on each branch, use a current limiting resistor. Then connect each branch in parallel to 12V.

description.text:
The Swoosh Spinner: handsomely designed and ergonomic

I created this spinner with two goals in mind: comfort and speed. It was actually made at the request of a friend who wanted something that spins fast, and most importantly, something that's easier to spin in one hand. With this, I got to work. Several days of testing and prototyping, I settled on this design.

The grooves in the side of each bar are sculpted to fit the average persons index finger, which allows for better leverage while spinning. Though it's designed around the index finger, you can also quite comfortable spin it with your middle and ring finger, if you so choose.

This design is also my first design to feature a variable fillet. I used it mainly to make it more comfortable to spin, but it also makes it look really cool.

Technical Specifications

-Outer Diameter: 80mm

-Bering to Bearing Diameter: 52mm

-Height: 7mm

-Bearing Type: 608 (any skateboard bearing)

Prusa

Prusa Clone

Notes:

Though this is entirely optional, sanding it with a fine grit sandpaper gives it an awesome matte finish which looks great on this design. Again, entirely optional. It will still look great with no post print refinements.

A 3-D rendering of a Dini surface. The design starts in Sage, export to X3D (resulting file included), then import X3D into Blender. In Blender, edit to remove artifacts Sage leaves behind, like a cube of lines around the figure, then "thicken" the surface so that Cura can recognize it as a solid object:

  1. select Properties -> Modifiers (wrench icon) -> Add Modifier -> Solidify
  2. set Thickness to 0.2 and click Apply

Now export to STL, then import STL into Cura. In Cura, scale (because graph units in Sage become millimeters in Cura) and situate figure on print platform, then export STL again to form the STL thing file here.

Here is the Sage code to generate the figure:

x=var('x')
f(x)=cos(x)+ln(tan(x/2))
u,v=var('u,v')
parametric_plot3d([cos(u)*sin(v),sin(u)*sin(v),f(v)+0.1*u],(u,pi/2,6*pi),(v,0.2,2),aspect_ratio=1)

Since Sage is Python-based, be sure to check line breaks.

title: Laser-cut brackets for wall mounting pretty much anything

description.text:
More for inspiration than anything else. You'll have to redraw the clip parts can hold whatever you're mounting if it's a different size. I mounted 8mm cedar planks.  
Some design tips, if you're redesigning for your specific case:  
Don't use acrylic. It's very brittle on that axis, and it will shatter and dump your entire wall on the ground.  
Make sure your material can fit in the slots of your wall rails! I had to dremel them down.  
Those curvy bits are necessary. When you push your planks (or whatever) into the clips, those curves will sort of uncoil and provide stress relief.

title: Motor levelling mounts for Banggood Falcon 250/Pro

description.text:
These levelling shims simply screw between the motor and existing Falcon 250 motor mount. This allows you to retain the transparent mount and the LEDs underneath.

All you'll need are some spare M3 screws of differing lengths (6/8/10mm). Don't allow the screws to penetrate the motor too far.

When you have done this, you'll need to recalibrate the accelerometer for the new level flight. There are tutorials for this online. If you don't do this and try to fly in beginner mode, the quadcopter will not fly level for you.

MAKE SURE THE SCREWS ARE TIGHT AND/OR HAVE LOCTITE ON THEM. One of my motors loosened and flew off into the big blue yonder. Needless to say the quad 'failed to maintain a correct flight path' after this happened.

UPDATE: I removed these to put the motors back at 10 degree angles, then recalibrated the accelerometer with the quadcopter on a 10 degree incline (so the props are horizontal). This works fine, with the quad able to hover well and perform well in the air.

I'll design some horizontal, transparent motor holders with LED pockets for the Falcon 250 pro when I have time.

author: AndrewFromOz

print_settings.Notes:: I always print with 4 shells so if you print 3, your infill will have to be a higher percentage.

description.text:
I decided to create a new filament roller that is smaller than my original. This is small, lighter weight, and uses less filament than my original design.

The rollers are a larger diameter than they needed to be but that was to increase torque and lower rolling resistance of the spools. That puts less stress on the extruder stepper motor.

There are small recesses to add rubber feet on the bottoms of the sides.

Print each file twice to make a full roller set.

UPDATE 9JUL2017: I have added locking clips to prevent the roller sides from coming apart. This works great even if the bearings have a loose fit. Print 2 and attach per the photos

Requires: 4 x 608zz bearings

Please post your makes and comments! Thanks!

Printer:

Hatchbox Alpha

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I always print with 4 shells so if you print 3, your infill will have to be a higher percentage.

Some light sanding of the bearing posts might be required

Some light sanding might be required to fit the ball bearings on to the posts. You could also just heat the posts with a lighter and push the bearings on instead.

After I pushed the bearings on, I heated the end of each post and flared it out to prevent the bearings from ever walking themselves off of the posts. I don't think it would happen but just to be safe I flared them.

comments.text: UPDATE 9JUL2017: I have added locking clips to prevent the roller sides from coming apart. This works great even if the bearings have a loose fit. Print 2 and attach per the photos

description.text: A basic stand for blackberry Q10, works well for beside and charging. Not fancy, but a good place to start if you want to make some modifications.

A 3-D rendering of a hyperbolic paraboloid ("saddle" or "potato chip" surface), part of my "Gallery of Quadric Surfaces." The design starts in Sage, export to X3D (resulting file included), then import X3D into Blender. In Blender, edit to remove artifacts Sage leaves behind, like a cube of lines around the figure, then "thicken" the surface so that Cura can recognize it as a solid object:

  1. select Properties -> Modifiers (wrench icon) -> Add Modifier -> Solidify
  2. set Thickness to 0.1 and click Apply

Now export to STL, then import STL into Cura. In Cura, scale (because graph units in Sage become millimeters in Cura) and situate figure on print platform, then export STL again to form the STL thing file here.

Here is the Sage code to generate the figure:

x, y = var('x,y')
plot3d(x^2-y^2, (x,-1.2,1.2), (y,-1.2,1.2), aspect_ratio=1)

Since Sage is Python-based, be sure to check line breaks.
